dc:description: *CSRP1* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant congenital heart disease in 2017 (Kamar et al., PMID: 29326753). One variant (frameshift) that has been reported in three affected probands from one family in one publication (PMIDs: 29326753) is included in this curation. This variant was not scored due to assertion for digenic inheritance with *TRPS1*. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss-of-function. This gene-disease relationship is supported by experimental evidence (expression-level evidence; Descartes fetal expression data, PMID: 17592114). Expression-level evidence in zebrafish with knockdown of CSRP1 is indicative of cardiac bifida. In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between *CSRP1 *and autosomal dominant Congenital Heart Disease has been disputed and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role CSRP1 plays in this disease. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Congenital Heart Disease GCEP on the meeting date July 2nd 2024 (SOP Version 10).
curationReasonDescription: There is only one case of genetic evidence, which is not scored as a digenic mode of inheritance is suggested. Thus, disputed was determined to be the appropriate classification.

evidence.dc:description: Please note that the CSRP1 variant is p.Glu154Valfs*99. This case is not scored as a digenic inheritance involving the TRPS1 and CSRP1 variants is suggested.

CSRP1 mutant (p.Glu154Valfs*99) had significantly reduced transcriptional activity of cardiac promoters such as NPPA in HEK293 cells. The CSRP1 protein was shown to interact with TRPS1 and mutations in either gene disrupted interaction between the two proteins in immunoprecipitation and Western Blot analysis.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lebanese family, 3 affected individuals with CHD

family.rdfs:label: Lebanese family, 3 affected individuals with CHD

member.rdfs:label: p.Glu154Valfs*99 (non-scorable)
member.detectionMethod: They also evaluated a 119 CHD-linked gene panel.
member.phenotypeFreeText: small perimembranous VSD;  lower extremity bilateral postaxial polydactyly, right hand syndactyly with postaxial finger formation, and left hand postaxial polydactyly with syndactyly in the 4th and 5th digits

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: four siblings with cardiac phenotype: one had patent ductus arteriosus (she died at 7 yrs. due to pulmonary issue); another had ventricular septal defect; the other two (pair of twins) had atrial septal defect and patent foramen ovale (the latter condition does not count as congenital heart disease); four individuals had polydactyly

evidence.dc:description: Fetal expression data from Descartes shows very high expression in this heart.
evidence.rdfs:label: Fetal Expression Data (Descartes), NOT from this PMID

evidence.dc:description: In wildtype zebrafish, expression of CSRP1 is found in the endoderm below the cardiac mesoderm in addition to in the anterior part of the cardiac mesoderm. The mutant zebrafish (with knockdown of CSRP1 via two morpholino oligonucleotides against CSRP1) show cardiac bifida. In the mutants, the expression domain of GATA4 moved laterally, causing a bigger gap in the middle portion. HAND2, which has expression in the cardiac mesoderm of the wild type, had expression in wider regions of the mutant. Expression of endodermal markers like GATA5 and BMP2B was found in the endoderm below the cardiac mesoderm in the wild type. In the mutants, this expression was expanded.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish expression analysis
